description: I think this is my new favorite taco shop in the city. It's just a couple blocks for my office which makes weekly taco fixes necessary. :)
author: Emily M.

description:
I walked in at 2pm on a Monday afternoon, deciding to give this place a chance regardless of its terrible reviews. I ordered a Super Steak Burrito and received it in less than two minutes at $7- the only positive about this experience.

However, I quickly regretted my lunch choice after taking the initial bite. I have NEVER had a worst Super Steak Burrito in my life. And I'm Mexican. The steak didn't resemble steak, it was like a "carne en su jugo", or a meat stew, watery and flavored like meat stew. This taste of this "meat juice" was so overpowering too. 

Super Steak Burritos are supposed to have a bite and be somewhat chewy, with a wonderful creaminess to it due to the crema and guacamole. This burrito had no bite, no substance, it was a watery, mushy, flavorless mess. You could literally drink the inside.

The rice was also over cooked and watery, the tortilla was too thin to hold it all, and the size was more like Child Size than a Super Burrito. This experience was utterly disappointing. Even the salsa that the counter boy snuck me couldn't have saved it.
author: Itzel R.

description:
The food is good but it's overpriced in my opinion for what you get. You have to pay in cash which I think is annoying and of course they have an ATM which charges you $2.50 to get cash. Great way for them to make money but I'm not a fan. 

Also, $2 for guacamole per taco!?!? Seriously!?!? That's a little outrageous. 

Unless something changes on price, I won't be back.
author: Matt M.

description:
bitches are a rip off. 
$20 for 2 shrimp tacos with extra shrimp (because it's originally made with only 3 little shrimps) smdh
flattest nacho plate like bitch where are the nachos?!
author: Alee P.

description: Got breakfast burrito with bacon, pico de gallo, and black beans but all I got is beans, beans, and more beans. Additionally, the burrito is SO WATERY that every time I bit into it, I didn't get the burrito (let alone the bacon), instead I was too busy wiping here and there because the beans and salsa juices are leaking EVERYWHERE from my jeans, my sweater, hands, and even my keyboard! I ordered it with Ritual and almost convinced they ordered me a soup burrito instead of breakfast burrito. Looking at the pictures, there's nothing in there but beans and the juices everywhere. Ew.
author: Rosita O.

description:
I really don't get all the negative reviews.

Yeah, it's mediocre Mexican food.  Yes, it's cash only.  No, they're not going to treat you like royalty.

This place serves up decent food in fairly big portions at rock bottom prices.  Where else can you go in FiDi with $6 and actually get a decent meal?
author: Jason F.

description:
Yea...not coming back here again. 

I asked for a super burrito with no guacamole. What the lady thought I said was "baby burrito with no rice."  I'm not sure how that translates. I even told her what I wanted and she didn't listen and gave me something I don't want. There's no flavor in it at all and not satisfying. Big mistake. There are better places to check out than this.
author: Me V.

description:
NOT all El Faro's are created equal! This shady little dump is nothing like my local El Faro in SSF. (which is awesome and my guilty pleasure) 

My "Happy" burrito so small.. the sauces not the same ..  the thing landed in the trash it tasted so bad. 

I told the cashier that this was like a kids burrito and that it was too bad, since work around the corner. He honestly cared less, did also not care about me writing a review.. so here it is. 

Complete "cash only, no receipt provided" dump!! Never going back there again..  Disgusting, dirty, dark and just shady place..  not even sure if the food is up to health standards. Someone should really send the health department to this place.
author: Beatrix F.

description:
WOW... I ordered the Super Burrito (~$7.00) with Al Pastor.

Please note that this was not a super in size... I guess their idea of "super" is adding sour cream and guacamole.  

The Al Pastor was really salty.  I could not taste any other flavor besides the salty meat.  Next the rice was hard and dry.  Either it was from the edge of the pan or it was not freshly made.

There was plenty of seating, but its a bit dark inside.

OK - I have been burping Al Pastor for hours after eating it.  Now I have a case of potential food borne illness.  Only thing I ate was the burrito.  Lucky for me, no cramps.  About 10 hours from lunch till my first trip to the bathroom.  Need to flush my system and hydrate.

Up all night with chills.  

First and last time at this place.   I tempted faith once... don't want to push it.

48 hours later...its OVER!!  I was up 2 nights in the bathroom.... not worth the $7.00 burrito.   But thanks!!  I lost 10 lbs for the new year!!
author: Jerry W.

description:
I don't understand the negative reviews for El Faro, it is one of the best burritos in the area.

I've been coming to El Faro for ~5 years as I have worked close by and I consistently think their Mole burrito is one of the best lunch items you can find when looking for a quick bite.

El Faro will continue to be a consistent lunch spot for me! Only negative is that it is cash-only.
author: Jon C.

description: Was making our way to the pier and was super hungry. My bf didn't want to check Yelp and wanted to just give it a go.....bad mistake. Food was disgusting, the bathrooms were very sketchy. I didn't feel safe lol. Then my bf went to the men's bathroom and the doors were short where he could see a staff member shitting......talk about super ghetto. They need to revamp this place and the menu.
author: Lynn C.

description:
Was looking for a new burrito spot and decided to try it out.  It was very disappointing and unsatisfying.  I thought the name El Faro meant it was affiliated with El Farolito on 24th and Mission, but they are two completely different businesses.

Ordered a super carne asada burrito.  You get one scoop of boiled beef preprepared and sitting out in a tin.  You get guacamole thinly applied on the tortilla by the back of a spoon.  

By the time it was rolled up, it was about a little less than half the size of any other super burrito you're used to getting.  

They don't grill your meat to order; they don't toast your tortilla, they're skimpy on sauces.  

Why ever come back?
author: John M.

description:
My go-to Mexican spot downtown. I was introduced to their breakfast burritos which are like one I've never had; I would say it is their sauce they add over their burritos(if you're not a fan of spicy, I would try without their sauce). I would have taken a picture but I got too excited once I got my breakfast burrito. 

If you're looking for a bomb-ass taqueria downtown, this is the one I would recommend; you WONT spend $10+ for basic-ass Mexican food here. I tend to lean more towards their carnitas and salsa verde.

THEY ARE CASH ONLY but have an ATM on-site.
author: Francois T.

description:
If you want truly mediocre Mexican Food, full of attitude like you are in a snooty French restaurant as a patron who must cater to THEM (rather than them making the client happy or treating them fairly), or something also akin of the soup Nazi and like some abuse while you hand over CASH, as they only take cash, but conveniently offer an ATM to collect a $3 fee on top of the bank fee you'll be paying of $3 for your mediocre Mexican food with an attitude, be sure to eat here.

Cheap in their approach and RUDE as can be.

If you want a place that has NO issue putting the dressing or guacamole on the side that you are ALREADY PAYING FOR (if you don't like it mixed in) without trying to charge you or denying you while pointing to their "We Reserve the Right to Refuse Service" sign, who TAKES debit cards and greets you with a smile and has MORE to offer as well as some FRESH GREENS, do yourself a favor and SKIP this place, instead go to Cantina Verde in SOMA on the Corner of Front & Pine, whom is reasonably priced for FiDi.

This was like my 10th "bad" experience there and I don't like a tongue lashing or side-ways glare or emotional abuse along with throwing my money at a business. 

So I won't give them my business anymore. I honestly cannot believe they get away with all they do: DO NOT AT ALL CARE ABOUT THE CUSTOMER'S EXPERIENCE. Worst place ever!! Then they wonder why I am upset? You are regularly RUDE and cheap and WHILE I TIP YOU TOO! Last money I will ever give them. Will give my money to another establishment. Respect matters.
author: Amanda J.

description: 4 chips on my plate. Definitely not coming back here. And they even tried to short me a dollar. Wtf the el faro in the mission way better
author: Al L.

description: Breakfast burritos with chorizo- soo good! I've been here numerous times with my coworkers and they get it right every time! We love this place. The staff is very friendly and fast. There have been days we've been here twice in one day, because the burritos are THAT good! Go! You won't be disappointed :)
author: Nikha M.

description:
Budget Mexican food in a budget atmosphere. This is about the only restaurant in the area where you can get an affordable bite to eat. I got the special of the day, a Acapulco burrito. It was filled with shrimp, onions, and an orange sauce with rice as well. It's also served wet so if you don't like a wet burrito, then let the gals know ahead of time. 

Even stranger that they only had three choices of meat: ground beef, chicken, and pork. 

Service was a bit slow for me as they seemed to have forgotten my order and only when I eye balled the lady about my order did it make it to the grill. 

Overall I'd only return if I was in a budget mood for some cheap eats.
author: Bob K.

description: Overpriced for Mexican food. Tastes like cafeteria cheese pizza. Would not recommend. Choose another place. They charge for everything. I make a better salsa.
author: Brandon Y.

description:
Consider yourself warned: this place is not in the same league as El Farolito in the Mission. This is your Fi-Di basic burrito spot.  Not bad for the price.  Don't expect huge portions and a ton of ingredients.  And because they can't fit a ton of ingredients in a medium/value sized burrito, the taste profile isn't as complex as places that can fit more ingredients with diverse flavors and textures.

Since Rico Mex closed, my current go-to burrito shop in the area is Caramba, but I still come to El Faro maybe twice a year when I'm in a rush (I work a block away in the Fi-Di every day). It'll do in a pinch.
author: J S.

description: I was super confused when it came to the ordering process, there was no one at the register when I went to order and then I proceeded to follow two guys at the back counter who were ordering food and they had already ordered but I could not get the three lady's attention long enough to tell them what I did want, after a minute or two of watching them run around in circles, finally I did get one to ask what I wanted BUT she turned away as I was listing the specific ingredients that I would like in my burrito (the Super burrito; cheese OR Guacamole) was was not all ingredients in a burrito as I had expected. All in all I somehow managed to get them to make a Chicken Burrito with rice, beans, sour cream and guacamole and I got the hell out of there after paying cash [only]. All in all the service was a weird and confusing situation but the food was decent even though it was a tad bit soupy than I am use to.
author: Austin D.

description: I gave this place a second try after I was disappointed because they don't accept credit cards and I was forced to use their ATM. I am disappointed again because the service was terrible and the employees didn't even smile. The burrito I ordered tasted fine, but there is nothing special about El Faro that will make me want to come back.
author: Michael M.

description: Expensive and horrible portion size.  The workers only puts half of a serving spoon of meat in the baby burrito!! Definitely will not be going back there again. Not worth the money!!
author: F. C.

description:
After hearing for years how delicious the breakfast burritos are, I finally had one this morning. NEVER AGAIN.

First of all, other reviewers who've said that El Faro serves soupy ass burritos were right. I was warned so I guess I shouldn't have been surprised when my burrito was soupy as hell. Like orange liquid leaking all over the foil, puddling on your desk, multiple napkins kinda soupy. No thanks.

The egg portion is essentially an omelet type thing they throw in with the mix of ham, chorizo, and bacon, although I didn't see any bacon in mine and only had maybe two bites of chorizo. The ham was gross so I picked out the little pink cubes. The refried beans are like molten lava so be careful when taking your first bite. 

Not worth the calories. It was also super salty! They have a nice spicy salsa but they charge for it, so eff that.
author: Bella L.

description: I came here today for lunch. Very affordable quality food. The staff is also very friendly and attentive. The burrito was  filling with leftovers for later or the next day. They have wheat and spinach tortillas too which is an added bonus. Will go again.
author: Kam H.

description: Avoid this place at all costs. Food is ultra greasy and salty. Made me sick after eating their Burrito.
author: John R.

description: Wow, you know a place is good when there is a huge line before the lunch hour even starts. The place only takes cash, so beware, but bring the cash with you and buy all the tacos because they are delicious. So are the tamales. Make sure and get their homemade salsas on top of the carnitas tacos and pork tamales. Wow wow wow!
author: Luis P.

description: This place is the best place in town to get a burrito which is even tastier than a 4 year old frozen gas station burrito. As you soak in the wonderful DMV esque atmosphere you may think to yourself "man! I have arrived in this world!" An hour later you'll feel no regrets as that artfully presented tan colored arrangement of costco quality ingreedients nourish your soul from within and inspire you to continue exploring the culinary ocean that is San Francisco.
author: Tim T.

description: Coming here was a mistake, never going back. Food is low low quality, and service is horrible. Overcharged me and then yelled at me. Also they're cash only but it doesn't say so on the door. Not until you're ready to pay. Major language barrier. The prices are cheap, but the food and service are way cheaper. Not worth the $3 you'd save.
author: Katie L.

description:
This place is great and it's been here for at least eight years. Where else can you get a regular burrito for 6$? 

That said you either love it or you don't. I recommend the regular burrito with chile verde. Everyone here is always nice and I'll continue to support them despite bad reviews from those who expect the same thing they get from the newer places that have opened in the area.
author: L L.

description:
just took a chance to pop in on our old spot from the 80's... the prices surely have changed and the choices have been totally downsized...  I understand you're in the financial district...but a burrito with no meat or sour cream pretty overpriced for my budget... Now you have to pay for the chips and salsa? Wow~ times have changed... 
Don't think we'll make that mistake again...  will try the one on Mission St next time I'm in the mood for a taqueira style restaurant in SF~
author: deborah s.

description: The BEST burrito in this area. I am shocked at all the low star reviews. All their meats are good but the chicken mole is exceptional. The ladies making the food are so friendly and accommodate any special request you might have. It's the only place you can get incredibly full for under $8. And they have a delicious breakfast burrito. Thank you El Faro!
author: Will C.

description: I came here at 7:25am to grab a breakfast burrito before work. When I got to the restaurant there were about 5-6 people in line before me. The 3 women making burritos were so disorganized and flustered, it seemed like none of them knew what they were doing. I waited until 7:55am and only moved up 3 spots in line before I had to leave to make it to work on time. None of the staff updated anyone on why it was taking so long or apologized for the ridiculous wait. Everyone in line was extremely annoyed. It shouldn't take 30+ minutes to make 5 burritos with already cooked ingredients. Not the way I wanted to start my day.
author: Mike T.

description:
This place is crap. I went in and attempted to order two chicken tacos with guacamole. What I got was about 7 minutes of confused conversation among the cooks before being walked over to the cash register and then being charged $14. I can understand charging more for guacamole (they do not have a 'super' option for their tacos), but there was definitely not $1 worth of guacamole nonetheless $3. 

Ultimately the food was not great, the service was bad, and the add-on pricing was ludicrous. I will not return or recommend.
author: Carrie D.

description:
I can see why the place was empty during lunch time. They charge extra for EVERYTHING.. The super burrito does not come with lettuce or tomatoes an d if you want them its extra.. They barely put any meat on my burrito. It's the smallest super burrito I've seen in my life!! 
The baby burrito in the Mission are twice the size.. No flavor at all

DO NOT GO HERE EVER!!!!!!! Ewwwwwww
author: Ayana K.

description:
I'm not sure why there are so many negative reviews, but this is a solid Mexican option for those looking for breakfast in SOMA. The breakfast burritos are HUGE and come with beans, cheese, eggs, bacon, ham, chorizo, salsa (mild or spicy - go for the spicy), and enchilada sauce. They are very flavorful, and are cheap compared to similar places in the area ($4.45 for a small and $5.95 for a super). I highly recommend their breakfast burritos.

As a side note, I don't care for their lunch options. Their chicken tends to be soggy, and one of the sauces they use in the burritos has a weird flavor that clashes with the rest of the burrito.
author: Josh P.

description: Drove across town expecting El Farolito quality but got a soggy breakfast burrito no bigger than McDonald's breakfast burrito for the same price.
author: Matt T.

description: Decent hole in the wall. The breakfast burrito was surprisingly good, I would come back for sure. The burrito is hot and the ingredients are well melded together (I guess some would call it soupy). I didn't have major leakage in mine, but it was very tasty.
author: Jonah K.

description: I have only ordered the breakfast burritos here but I've never had a problem. Every time I get them for the office people love them so I'm not sure why people are bashing the place. Being from LA I'm used to hole in the wall Mexican spots, those are usually the best. If you want a 5 star Mexican spot this isn't the place but if you want fast Mexican food on the go, then come here.
author: Mal L.

description:
The great thing about this place is now we know where the worst Mexican food restaurant is. This joint is bad, really really bad. I'm blown away that it has such a good overall rating. 

The grilled chicken burrito didn't make me sick but it was so boring I ended up throwing it  out. If I could choose between going here and Taco Bell I'd go to Taco Bell every time.
author: Justin S.

description: I have been coming here for over a decade now and always always have the same thing, big breakfast burrito with hot sauce. This is the best I have had and the same ladies have been here as long as I have been coming. Doesn't look like much but you will always see city workers, firemen, police and construction guys packing this place. Definitely worth any type of wait. Excellent and I hope it never goes away! Thanks El Faro!
author: Keith G.

description: Come on in. CASH ONLY. They do have an ATM machine by the door. Avoid the crowds by being first in line. The breakfast burrito is amazing, it reminds me of my mom's home cooking. If you're not big on spicy, tell them to go easy on the sauce. These folks are fast under pressure.
author: Krys K.

description: Dude let's put it this way I've never criticized any restaurant in my life till today! This was the worst experience I had! I got a super burrito which was nasty! Horrible! While eating the burrito the rice tasted like shiiiiit! The salsa tasted like it was rotten or something! Plus I wanted a chicken burrito but they had no chicken and instead I got steak I should have walked out from there but unfortunately I didn't .. On top of that they give you 3 chips? After spending up to $10! (WTF 3 chips) The customer service is horrible! I honestly want them to get a food inspection ASAP! I regret not going to Portico which is literally right next door! But unfortunately I have a soft spot for Mexican food and made the worst decision by going there! My stomach hurts and honestly if in my power I wish no one goes there again!!!! It's horrible! And not worth your time or money! I will never go there again! Mark my words!! I regret spending my lunch break there! SMH! I will give it no stars!!!!!!!!
author: Diwij T.

description: Staff is uninteresting and unfriendly and if you can't make a baby burrito that won't fall apart while I'm eating it......I could have had a better experience at Taco Bell!
author: pip t.

description: Super burrito, carne asada, with sour cream, spicy, and wet (extra sauce gravy on the side free). The best burrito you'll ever eat!
author: Shayenne G.

description:
Pros:
 - Fast
 - Cheap

Cons:
 - Got the 'Super Burrito' with chicken. It wasn't very super.
author: Josh S.

description:
The food =  Meh! 
The CASH ONLY and $1.00 for Chips  = 2 thumbs down. This place is so stingy. I won't be back. Try the one in Concord, CA ... It's Much, Much better!
author: Reina S.

description: The service here is horrible..the women preparing the food didn't wash there hands. The quality of food isn't pleasing to look at. I asked the woman preparing my burrito can I try the meat before she made it. She refused to. After my burrito was prepared I was having second thoughts about even buying the burrito. When I finally qot to the front my meal came up to $10 not including my drink. Then the cashier told me the chips were an extra charge weather it was for here or to go. I will never spend my money here again
author: Jasz S.

description: This place is a little bit of Mexican heaven.  Rice, beans to perfection.  Salsa was tasty, quick service with a decent sized eating area.  I recommend it highly.
author: Yolanda V.

description: El Faro is honest food with authentic flavors and attractive prices. Everyday at lunch there's a long line that goes fast. The long line shows how popular El Faro is. The reason the line moves so quickly is that 3 wonderful cooks are behind the counter fulfilling orders. In addition to their famous burritos, they also have classic combination plates, tortas hot sandwiches, salads, and specials. El Faro doesn't try or need to compete with trendy places that add kale to everything. El Faro serves good, hearty food that fuels the men and women building the new high-rise towers, working/coding in offices, or shopping in the neighborhood. Cash only with an ATM near the front.
author: Ted C.

description:
The food was spicy which I liked. Some of the ingredients are plain, but it's made up for in size and good chicken. 

Pros:
Good prices compared to the rest of SF
Chips and salsa are resonably priced
Chicken is good
Burritos are very large

Cons:
Cash Only
author: Michael D.

description:
What's with the bad reviews? Admittedly I'm not well versed on their entire menu offerings but it seems like a mom-and-pop type of establishment as it seems to not have a certain corporate identity attached to it. I was told about this spot by my boss on how they have the "best breakfast burritos". I love breakfast burritos so I was challenged to try this place out. Their breakfast burrito is OFF. THE. HOOK. It's very tasty and is better when you get the salsa on the side so you can control how much is put in there because sometimes too much salsa can ruin a burrito, but the eggs, the beans, the chorizo and cheese was just too heavenly of a combination to pass up. 

The ladies behind the counter are very fast and very hard working and I have never been disappointed by a burrito they have made for me and I've been coming back almost once or twice a week now. The only real downside this place has going for it is the fact that it does feel unorganized where you have to stand in line to order your food then take your food to another line to pay where, get this, it's cash only. Oi! As someone who doesn't carry a lot of cash around with them, if at all, it would be wise to at least keep an emergency $10 bill handy just in case you're feeling hungry and want a breakfast burrito. This isn't directed at El Faro specifically but this is the year 2015 and there are still cash only establishments around? Weird. 

But anyways, the breakfast burrito is great. Maybe next time I'll try their lunch menu or one of the "fan creations" they have posted on one of the glass walls. I want a burrito named after me, that sounds pretty cool, but yeah this place is very tasty despite it having an awkward set up initially.
author: Daniel R.

description:
The ladies are super nice, the breakfast burrito is the best in all of downtown SF, and when I go for lunch, the Trisha Goddard show playing on the TV is the perfect unintentionally comical shitty programming to zone out to in the middle of a tough work day.

The food is not healthy, but if you order the right thing, it really hits the spot, and it's always been consistent for me.

I recommend the Chile Relleno burrito (add guac) for lunch, or the while wheat tortilla breakfast burrito for breakfast on the go...

The ladies know me now, and are nice to me because I am nice to them.  Kindness works, people!
author: Kristen R.

description: Really bad.  Food:  tasteless, flavorless.  Not really good homemade Mexican food.   The servers are also the cooks?  It's true.  The decor ambiance are kitch cafeteria, without the kitch.  Sorry.  Nothing good to share here at all....oh yeah, low prices?  Well you get what you pay for.
author: John H.

description:
Someone calls asking after a delivery that is now 45 minutes late and your response:

"Tough shit he'll get there when he gets there"

Enough said.
author: Mark F.

description: I was the only patron in the store at 6:50 am on a Tuesday. The cook/server saw me but continued to keep her back to me for over 5 minutes. I think she woke up on the wrong side of the bed. I walked out. I don't like being treated badly. Plenty of other places to eat in the area.
author: Jim R.

description:
I read this review from 2008, six years later, nothing seemed changed.  

This place really needs a face lift.   If nothing else paint the place white and use a heck of a lot of washing walls, floors etc.  (-1)

The food is less than ok, and then covering it by making it way too salty.. (-1) yet behind the salt, they are somewhat tasty.  I hated the fact they force you to buy chips.   I also didn't like the skinny burrito, and then when I asked for a carnitas, they were obviously being cheap.  The presentation of carnitas meat wasn't good at all.  (-1)   Look guys.. people go to El Faro for a meal. If you can't cut it, don't open the doors, plain and simple.  I would rather pay an extra buck than get to get nickle and dime burritos. This place wouldn't survive if this place was anywhere near the Mission District.
author: Tito Y.

description:
Oh man this place is awesome.  I've been coming here weekly for a few years and have yet to get tired of it 

They have a nice selection of meats in the front, but they also hold some good stuff in the back for special requests.  I'm not a big fan of their chicken, but the 'al pastor' is amazingly good.  If you come here then make sure to get a spicy al pastor super burrito wet style and covered in salsa.
author: Andrew L.

description:
At first I was excited by the low prices and variety in the menu.  They have relleno burritos!  The size of the burrito was great for the price and I was eager to try it out.

Unfortunately I was a little dissapointed by the taste.  It was a little bit bland and the ingredients seemed a bit low quality.

The nail in the coffin was that I spent the rest of the day on the toilet.  In retrospect the place didn't seem very sanitary.  I will spend the extra couple dollars and eat somewhere cleaner and better quality next time.  Don't bother visiting here unless you are very cheap and don't mind bad food as long as you get a lot of it.
author: Solomon S.

description: My God, this place sucks! The food tastes old and is microwaved right in front of you. Taco Bell is much more authentic and not microwaved.
author: Richard G.

description: Eat a carnitas burrito and a soft drink for under $10 not was it cheap but really good!! I found my spot in downtown Frisco!!!!!
author: Pete S.

description: I ordered a carnitas super burrito at 2:30 and at 9:30 I have the shits. Thank you very much it's now 10:30 and I still have the shits.  The burrito itself was very bland and totally not worth the extra trips to the bathroom. I would suggest eating somewhere else.
author: Brandon B.

description:
Just had a cheese & Gauc burrito, though it's good, it tasted more like bean burrito in Taco Bell. 
Not sure if it is just for today,  they are only accepting cash, kind of surprising for me.
It's cheap but not so hygienic though. 
Descent quantity which makes sense for the price they charge.
Their made their menu with permutation& combinations of few varieties, which is kind of confusing.
author: Venkat K.

description:
Far better.

Bad: http://www.yelp.com/biz/el-faro-san-francisco#hrid:zRy7Csfhf5RQhILYY1WH8w 

Expensive: http://www.yelp.com/biz/el-faro-san-francisco-2#hrid:ZEGH2hXErh9hMXqer5NogQ 

This location has been the best of the bunch. Grilled chicken on a roll topped with black beans, lettuce and tomato. Not quite a torta but close.

Surprised to see everything made so fresh and with little excess oil. Even the price wasn't that excessive. $7 and change for a filling sandwich felt about right.

Brick interior adds some character and the entire staff was friendly and welcoming.

Fourth and final El Faro is in the Haight. Perhaps it will finally be a fourth star.
author: Jason B.

description: Had a carne asada burrito and what i got was a rice burrito with a hint of carne asada. Never coming back again.
author: J S.

description:
I came here for the first time during my first few weeks of starting work in the FiDi.

I've come to learn that El Faro is probably the only cheap, quick, and delicious Mexican place downtown. 

I would recommend the pork super burrito. Even though they recently remodeled, you still have to look past their crummy facilities because fast Mexican burritos doesn't get much better than this in the FiDi.
author: Bryan L.

description:
Just had a Super Chorizo burrito. $7. No salsa or chips and very skinny. 

I could not see any sour cream or gauc anywhere! 

Chorizo tastes same as at their kearny location - decent but not amazing. Staff unhelpful. 

Overall, terrible service and a bit skinny. But the taste and quality of what i did get was pretty good by fi-di standards. still better than chipotle or the hipster taco joints...
author: David P.

description: Fairly quick service. People are nice. I got the carne asada baby super burrito, which was decent but had too much beans for my liking. Decently filling, but I think I'd rather just get the regular burrito and split it into two meals.
author: Veronica C.

description: this was the worst burrito ever ate let's just call it a soup Burrito you have to suck it  I am not gonna waste my time  writing about this place
author: Mochi R.

description:
I ordered a super burrito. Why guacamole is included by sour cream isn't, I don't know.

Anyway, I watched my burrito being assembled. A smear of refried beans - like it was a plating on the Food Network. A scattering of rice. A sprinkle of cheese, then my meat, sauce (good) and guacamole. 

All wrapped up, thinner than a bottle of Mexican Coke. 

Burritos are supposed to be bigger than your head. The ingredients they skimped on are inexpensive. 

I must find another downtown burrito option.
author: Libby S.

description: This place is really good if you are looking for not-so-american mexican food. I got the regular burrito with chicken and guacamole
author: Josh T.

description: In terms of Mexican Food in the financial district - I would have to go with Caramba, Verde, and Orale Orale. I asked for the grilled chicken burrito. That was a mistake. My friend recommended I ask for a "wet" burrito. That was another mistake.
author: Nikhil V.

description:
Okay, I wasn't going to say anything, but this place doesn't deserve all the bad reviews it's getting. It's not as good as it's sister store on Folsom (which used to be my all time favorite as a kid, though that may have something to do with the rosy colored glasses of youth), but it's got that location location going for it. I like the decor myself, under the assumption that a "real" taqueria should feel a little bit scuzzy, and this place delivers that with a tasty burrito to boot.

Misconceptions from the other reviews: 
1. They have three bean options, refried, black and... Pinto? (I dunno who gets Pinto beans on their burrito, but they have three beans). 
2. The ladies there are pretty darn friendly for taqueristas. They aren't beaming love rays at you 24/7, but neither are they making jokes about you in Spanish while they compile your taqueria takeout and I have gotten some genuine smiles upon entry.
3. Portions aren't that small. I'm a 5'11" 175 lb guy and I generally leave myself the butt end of the burrito for later consumption.

Things the other reviews got right: 
1. The burritos are kind of soggy. Doesn't make them awful, but there it is.
2. They don't give you chips for free. Who does anymore? Get over it.
3. They only accept cash. This is annoying, but not a deal breaker.

One thing I didn't see anyone else mention but kind of irks me:
They don't have Salsa Verde. I'm not going to lie to you, son. They don't have Salsa Verde.
author: Rio R.

description:
El Faro's business plan seems to be "Hey, we're in the Financial District, let's design our menu around the worst possible stereotype of White People and what they want in Mexican food"

The rice appears to be soaked in Campbells Tomato Soop. No choice of beans if you order a burrito - seems to be canned refried by default. The choice of meats is laughable too - literally "pork", "chicken", or "beef". No carnitas, no al pastor, no pollo al carbon. Too confusing for their insulting caricature of White People I guess. Instead you get what appears to be pork or beef roasted with absolutely no marinade or any kind of special preparation whatsoever, and chicken that looks like it's also floating in the Campbell's Soop. Way the hell too much salt in everything too.

A "baby burrito" is $4.75 after tax and you only get the crap rice, refried beans, and meat. If there's not even at least pico de gallo in it there's not even a point, it doesn't even qualify as Mexican food. Oh, no free chips/salsa with anything either. And the serving ladies talk shit if you take more than 0.5 nanoseconds looking over the menu. I guess they have a point, they've dumbed it down so much there's nothing to think about - pork crap, chicken crap or beef crap are your choices.

I don't mind being cruel, this food is overpriced garbage and I'm insulted that someone actually thought people would want to pay for this. The sad thing is their business strategy seems to be working as they've been here for like a decade. Seriously no point to eating here, espc. with Portico literally right next door, but apparently FiDi yuppies with more money than sense will keep it alive anyway.
author: Jeremy H.

description:
El Faro passes the sniff test as far as Mexican places in the FiDi go.  Some of their burritos are tasty.  I enjoy their chicken quesadilla as well, the melted cheese is served warm so it takes a little time to harden, giving you have a good window of opportunity for lunch.  For the most part, their meats are juicy and their portions are huge.  This is not always a good option for lunch since you will certainly get that full and bloated feeling inside...then really really sleepy.  The 1st St. location is quite annoying with their cash only payment system.  Seriously, WTF?  To somehow make up for that, they offer that dingy-lookin ATM machine in front that I think charges 20 bucks per transaction then sucks off an extra 200 bucks off your balance (then your own bank charges you another 45 bucks).  

Overall, food here is far from great...maybe far from good, but acceptable.  Three stars, I think, is fair.
author: Angel S.

description: Not sure why this place got such bad reviews... Came here on a Tuesday just before noon, wasn't busy so there was virtually no wait at all. I got a super burrito with al pastor (meat, cheese, guac, salsa, cilantro, onions, beans), and a side of chips and salsa. Came out to less than $10! Absolutely delicious and the women working were super friendly. Definitely a go-to lunch spot for authentic taqueria style food. CASH ONLY!
author: Tiffany M.

description: Lets start with this; it is a hole in the wall Mexican place. It is not very healthy. But that doesn't mean they dont make the best breakfast burrito in downtown SF. There are a lot of bad reviews here, but I think that is just people not taking it for what it is. My coworkers and I are regulars here. The salsa is deliciously spicy and the chicken quesadilla is amongst the best I have ever had.  The workers are very nice to me and often remember my order when I walk in. If you are looking for a dirty Mexican burrito, ignore the bad ratings and go here. Its CASH only btw.
author: Sean G.

description:
I've been here at least three times now and every single time I say I'm not going to come back. Personally, I don't think their food is very good and the people making it are never friendly. 

Also, they are cash only which is kind of inconvenient.

Two stars because a)it's not totally awful and b)it's super convenient to my office.
author: Rachel E.

description:
Arghh, I understand this is San Francisco. But this joint charges fairly high for its worn down atmosphere. Their burrito is full of juice, theres no way you can bite into this without it leaking on the other end. On top of that, theres very little meat and goods inside. The portion they give you is absurd for the price they charge.
 
If you walk up the alley to Stevenson st. Next to Yank Sing, there is another Mexican joint there thats cleaner called RixoMex. Go here instead. Larger tasty burritos thats not full of water.
author: HonestOpino N.

description:
First off, I'm really confused by the bad ratings.  I think people come here expecting the wrong thing.  Summary: Move this to the Mission, it'd be one or two stars; downtown, where it is, it gets four stars.

This is not as good as a host of burrito joints near where I live, in the Mission.  However, it is by far the best burrito joint where it actually *IS* downtown / by my office.  Similarly, I expect to pay about a dollar more for a burrito here than the Mission; that's fine. 

The burritos are a reasonable size; not as massive as some, but also a ludicrous single-serving, or a scant two servings.  They do a lot of the "extras" that made up a traditional superburrito as extra cost, which I appreciate, as you don't have to pay for stuff you don't want.  The ingredients were well done, and their red sauce was better than most.  

They charge extra for chips and salsa, but they use real probably homemade deep-fried chips, not of this pre-packaged tortilla chip crud that some places do - I highly recommend the chips, in fact. 

It has indoor seating, plus plenty of tables outdoors across the street.

This review is part of a series on lunch places near my office.
author: Zachary R.

description:
Nope. I ordered a Super Pollo Asado Burrito for lunch, when it arrived it looked like a Twinkie wrapped in tinfoil. It was about half the size of a Regular at Cancun. I pulled it out of the bag and said,

"This is a Super, seriously?"
"Oh, that's just what we call it", they replied.

Inside, it was just a gloppy mess of refried beans (which I didn't ask for and don't like), shredded cheese from a bag, some rice and a few small bits of chicken (were they even grilled?). Sour Cream and Guacamole were just some pureed slop that were wiped onto the tortilla there as an afterthought. No Fresh Salsa whatsoever. Total cost $7.

Seriously, do you serve this to your family at home? Or is this just some joke you play on gringos who don't know any better? I'll bring the rest of this back for my dog after work...
author: Gregory G.

description:
ehh i didn't LOVE their food. for all the money i spent craving for some good Mexican food. i wouldn't come back here. nothing compared to the mission. TMI (too much information) i had the runs towards the end of my food.  definitely not coming back here again.

the way their lines get during lunch hour, i thought i was alway going to come back. i was wrong.
author: Isa W.

description:
Not impressed at all with the Super Breakfast Burrito. It was soggy and very lackluster. I think there was salsa in my burrito and I've never had breakfast burrito with any wet ingredients. I also thought it was going to be huge considering there's a "small" version of it but it was sized at what you would expect a normal burrito to be. 

My burrito also got cold REALLY fast for some reason... might have been the cold weather, so that was a bummer.
author: Jason T.

description: I ordered a super burrito and I don't think I got a super burrito. No options for black beans. The one thing that is nice is the burrito take less than a minute to make (no joke). The taste wasn't bad for chicken, beans, rice and cheese. It wasn't terrible but I will not be returning.
author: Jeff B.

description:
I probably deserved this for not knowing better... horribly low Yelp rating and barely any customers during lunch.  The interior looks like a soup kitchen with the food probably not even being as good.  It's a shame they serve Mexican food of this quality this in a city with such highlights like those joints in the Mission.

Crispy Taco: This reminded of all those Ortega taco kits non-Mexican parents would make on Taco Night in the suburbs.  It was fancier than Taco Bell's hard tacos and the shell tasted more freshly fried.  However, after the retro novelty wore off, I think I was over it.

Beef Tamale: Did they really need to take my husk?  Part of the enjoyment of a tamale is to dig into the wrapper, which also acts to protect it from errant sauces.  The masa wasn't that special to begin with and got even worse when contaminated by my enchilada sauce.  The pulled beef inside was decent though, so glad they didn't use the ground beef from the hard taco.

Cheese Enchilada: The filling was satisfactorily cheesy, but the shell was rubbery.  Plus they used a microwave to melt my cheese as opposed to scooping from an already hot enchilada platter!

Rice: I'm not completely up on the various grades of rice, but this was pretty low with barely any grains maintaining the shape of a whole rice grain.  There was some colored flavoring that made it a little spicy, so a tad better than just plain.

Beans: There was a weird film that quickly congealed on top of my pile of refried beans as it went from barely warm down to room temperature.  I don't even want to guess what it was, but it wasn't tasty...
author: Adam B.

description: bleh....skinny little lunch time burrito filled with what seems like hot soup and rice. So gross.
author: L v.

description: Grubbin' 2-item combo. Crispy taco, chicken enchilada, beans rice. LA STYLE! Yum!
author: Brian J.

description:
This place is right down the street from me, and let me tell you, ignore all the bad yelp reviews.  You want an out-of-this-world burrito that weighs more than your head and only costs $5?  Then go to the Mission!  For the location (Financial District), this is a decent spot.

Could it be cheaper?  Sure!  But you can say that about almost any place in the Financial District.

Is the food quality?  Yes.  I've NEVER had a "watery" burrito or small portions.  I seriously think all these negative reviews were more due to the person than the place.  They were probably rude to the employees, something which I've seen happen on COUNTLESS occasions when grabbing a bite.  When you treat the employees making your food with disrespect, it's common sense to assume your meal may not be of Michelin 3 star standards.  I've been eating here on a consistent basis for the past year and have always enjoyed my meal.

I've taken a variety of people here for food: Vegetarians,  Gringos, you name it.  Not one person has had an "atrocious" experience like the yelp reviews would lead you to believe.  Maybe a 3 star experience for some, but mine have always been 4 or better.

For those of you who find this place to be disgraceful, you're probably better off getting something from Pasilla across the street.  More Americanized mexican food with the "clean" look you're probably more comfortable with.  Just don't expect an "authentic" experience there...no Chile Verde or Al Pastor to be found!
author: Aalok P.

description: My review mirrors most for this place. Recipe's are good, portion sizes are not. Ladies behind the counter making the food are notorious burrito Nazis. I've been coming here for 10 years (about twice a year) and they are very consistent in the previously mentioned areas. Premium location is no excuse for small portion size or bad attitude. It is an excuse for charging more but that's it.
author: Ragenvald G.

description:
Got the happy burrito. Didn't make me that happy. 

The burrito, like others have said, was soggy and pretty much one-note flavor, even though it was supposed to have all these ingredients in it. Probably the worst burrito I've ever had. The interior of this place really needs to be redone. 

Also... it was $9 for a burrito and a vitamin water!! Not outrageous for lunch in this area, but in my opinion, outrageous for mexican food!! Maybe I got too used to the delicious, cheap mexican food in LA... but still. 

If I'm craving mexican food, I'll go somewhere else.
author: Alison B.

description:
EL FARO, READ YOUR REVIEWS!!!  What happened to the El Faro of the 80's, the original SUPER BURRITO!  

I always leave here hungry, always.  Why do I come here? Close to work and always hopeful i'd get better than last time.

Why are you so skimpy with your cheap ingredients?  It's so obvious most of your reviews say your burritos are small, there's nothing super about them

I think i counted 5 corn chips on my plate and i had to ask for salsa.

Disappointed with the "Super Burrito" i thought i'd have a better experience with the LARGE QUESEDILLA.  Cheese, meat, and mass produced salsa.  For $8 Really???

And again I leave here hungry...for the last time.  

GET A CLUE!!!  Yes you deserve an average 2.5 star rating.  You've been operating this way for years.  I'm going to take an extra hour and have lunch at Taqueria Cancun 19th & Mission...the real deal.
author: Angelo M.

description: tHis place is as mediocre as it gets. nothing to see here folks. move on to the next. In the land of burritos this place really is really low on the totem pole. I dont even wanna explain in detail why. Just trust me. MMMMkay??!?!?!
author: Mario W.

description:
Ick. Just Ick. This has got to be the worst burrito I've had in SF yet. Sopping wet, only refried beans available, no flavor at all, and salsa that tastes like it came from a jar. To top it off, the burrito was tiny and cost $5.75 with no chips, and the women working there treated me like crap. 

Burrito FAIL.
author: Nadya K.

description:
What's to like?
1.  Pretty good burrito.  Typical chicken, rice, pinto beans, guacamole, sauce.  Sour cream is extra.  Comes together as your typical messy burrito.  Not going to win any awards.
2.  Fills you up for less than 10 bucks.
3.  Relatively quick

What's not to like?
1.  Could have a few extra options on the menu.
2.  Would like a few chips thrown in with my burrito.
3.  They asked about spicy multiple times.  I said yes each time.  Still not very spicy.
4.  The straw was too short for the large Coke.  Lol, I know. I know.  It's a small thing.  But small things separate the good from the great.

In the end, there is not a lot to differentiate El Faro from other burrito joints.  If you are close by and want a burrito, you will probably be a-ok with it.  Definitely no reason to go out of your way.

I have eaten at both the FiDi and SOMA location.  The same is true for both.

ps - my coworker really dislikes this place.  so, my views on it could be inaccurate.
author: Mark D.

description: So gross, there was a piece of hair inside my burrito. And it's the skinniest burrito I have ever seen in my entire life.....rip off and disgusting!!
author: Alex C.

description:
I usually come here for their breakfast burritos. The other choices that are close by are probably City Kinetics & Rico Mex on Stevenson (the alley). I'd say El Faro has the most "genuine" Mexican taste, but the darn thing is just so small! 

Their huevos rancheros are good though, and they include your choice of tortillas. Friendly service, too! They will even offer you a beer at 9:00am, hahaha.
author: Jorge S.

description: Authentic, filling, oozing with sauce, cheese, sour cream, and guacamole. Hands down the most satisfying burrito for breakfast I've had in a long time. An unexpected hit for such a modest looking establishment.
author: Jeff T.

description: The pricing is not clear and the help difficult to understand beyond ordering food. I have had better for the price in the same neighborhood.  The al pastor tacos were good but not great.
author: Gordon F.

description:
I don't think I've ever had such a soppy, poor excuse for a burrito.  What I ordered and what I got were two very different things.  Taste wise, I guess it was ok, but it was a challenge to eat.

Furthermore the damn thing peed on me.  I had watered down "hot" sauce all over me.
author: Clayton R.

description:
Sorry El Faro, you don't quite live up to the family name. 

- The burritos are okay but they are really small! Granted, I never eat a whole burrito, but that's not the point - the point is, a real burrito should be the size of a newborn child. Thus, I should have some to take home with me. Alas, that does not happen here. 
- They don't give you free chips - boo! That's up with that? Seriously, EVERY taqueria gives you free chips and salsa except this one.
- Their burritos have too much rice and not enough "juice", like sour cream and guacamole, so they're dry
- Not enough meat


On to the positive...
- Excellent selection of my favorite Mexican drinks like Penafiel and bottled sangria (non alcoholic), and horchata
- It's the only taqueria in the vicinity of my job
- Lots of seating

I really wish I could love you more - I really do.
author: Mariela D.

description:
I've been coming here for years, but today was the last time I'll ever step foot in this dump.  I waited in line 30+ minutes while they processed 4 large phone orders before even looking at me.  What kind of business ignores the guy standing directly in front of them?  It took less than 30 seconds to prepare my standard breakfast burrito order, and yet the unseen guy who called in 15 minutes after I had been standing in line got his first.  

And it was a crap, quick slap together mess of a breakfast at that.

Never again.
author: Bryce B.

description:
I've only ever gotten one thing here and I LOVE IT. A burrito with beans and cheese only, and some of the red sauce on the upper left side (if you are staring at the lady making it). It is excellent. I can't speak for anything else. But that bean & cheese burrito is the closest I get to SoCal Mexican food up here. And it's $5. I also get a small bag of chips and salsa and enjoy that too. This is my go-to bean & cheese burrito spot.

Minus one star because nothing else there really looks that good, so I stilck with my trusty frijoles con queso.
author: Jen E.

description: I have been going to one of the El Faro locations for years and today is the first day I walked out.  They now charge .75 cents for three day old shreaded iceberg lettuce.  Yes, if you would like garnish on your food you have to pay extra.  .75 cents for salsa on your burrito too!  I understand the .75 cents for sour cream and guac but really for a slice of tomato and some lettuce?  I strongly urge everyone to go to another place that actually serves well portioned and resaonably priced food.
author: Justin G.

description:
I walk by here sometimes and never went in. Yesterday I decided to walk in since I wanted some Mexican food. I ordered a beef burrito with guacamole and lettuce. Man can you say they were stingy with the portions.. they barely gave any guacamole (not to mention it was watered down) charged me an extra 60cents for some lettuce. And gave me five pieces of tortilla chips and one napkin. I'm like are you serious??? 

The service and staff are not friendly -  I was totally disappointed with my food and service here.  COLD burrito, salty beef and salsa = total disappointment and one unhappy customer. .I should of just went to Orale's or Baja Fresh. At least they have a salsa bar where you can get and pick your own sauces plus they give you free chips and better tasting salsa
author: V E.

description:
I don't know what I was thinking. I knew this place was bad, but I had a craving for a burrito, and these guys are close to my work. They don't have many options, the food quality is terrible, and the portions are tiny, so you're guaranteed to go away unsatisfied. I ordered a "super burrito" and wound up with this tiny, bland embarrassment. El Faro also makes you pay for salsa, which is just ludicrous. 

Never. Again.
author: Bitter J.

description: Not great.  Not totally awful.  I had 2 crispy tacos which were... ok.  Something comparable to Taco Bell, so there is no reason for me to definitely mark this spot as a place I need to come back to.  Although -- it's actually kind of nice that there aren't throngs of people waiting to come into this place -- especially during a hectic lunch hour.  But, if it was really amazing Mexican food, there would be way more ppl lining up at the door... 'nuff said.
author: Mel G.

description: I don't want to be cruel, but this is - bar none - the worst burrito I've ever had. 'Nuff said...
author: Jay N.

description:
Filing but not much else.  Not horrible, but nothing special.

The prices are too high to allow then to get away with such poor quality (they are only here becuase they would not survive closer to 16th and Valencia)
author: Mike V.

description:
I was very excited when I learned that El Faro's baby breakfast burritos contain ham, bacon and chorizo IN ADDITION to eggs and beans.  I was looking forward to a tasty cylinder of burrito love this morning 'cause I kinda over did it last night with the wine.

Twas not to be.

The burrito seemed to contain nothing but refried beans with a tiny smattering of ham.  No discernible bacon, chorizo or eggs to be found.  

FAIL.  And my head still hurts and now my stomach does too.
author: .Hon H.

description: I was so excited to go here for lunch today until I got my food. The service was horrible and the food was too. I've had better burritos. With this being a name that I was familar with I expected better. PLEASE do not eat here. You will be unpleasantly surprised.
author: Erika J.

description: Had their tacos dorados the other day and thought they were fantastic for a great price at about $9 for two (compared to other downtown San Francisco options).  They piled the tacos high with meat, beans, cheese, guacamole and salsa. Would definitely go back again.
author: Dan S.

description:
So this place looks like shit... You walk into what looks like a poor man's cafeteria, or maybe a laundromat, and you're drenched in artificial fluorescent light and you cringe a little bit as you approach the counter.  "Am I gonna get Montezuma's Revenge eating here?" you think to yourself.

So you go for it and order a chicken quesadilla.   They make it on the grill and you see them dump a bunch of chicken (or is it cat?) on a large flour tortilla.   They add plenty of cheese and you think they even throw on some oil for good measure.   What comes off the grill is oily and greasy and will clog the shit out of your arteries.   You decide that in order to speed up the heart attack you'll get a side of rice and beans as well.

You ask for the food to go and walk back briskly to your office, the raindrops pelting your head as you cross the street on Stevenson.   You get back to your office, break open the styrofoam to-go box, take a bite of your quesadilla...

"That's a pretty damn tasty heart attack!"

And the beans and rice aren't that bad either, though I would reproach the beans lack some additional melted queso on top.

All and all, El Faro may look like shit, but it's some pretty legit Mexican food.   Just don't go for the atmosphere.
author: David O.

description:
I realized that I don't have any one-star reviews yet.  And I stopped to think, hm....what's the WORST thing I've eaten in San Francisco?

Bingo.
author: Chris H.

description:
The Quest Continues:  It's important to remember that this review is based solely on their breakfast burrito which in my quest for one worthy of my time I walked four blocks to get.  In my last breakfast burrito review I said that of utmost importance was that none of the ingredients be microwaved which spoke to the quality of the contents.  When I walked in to El Faro and saw an actual griddle where they were cooking eggs I nearly leapt for joy.  Here is the breakfast burrito I have sought lo' these many weeks.  Finally, I thought, a replacement for the Foccacia cafe' breakfast burrito.

My first indication of trouble should have been the spoonful of runny refried beans they glopped onto the tortilla....I think a prior reviewer said it looked like runny baby goo.  I second that very descriptive and unfortunately accurate depiction.  I ended up not paying too much attention after that, so engrossed was I in the book that I was reading that the next time I actually saw the contents of my burrito was when I took my first bite.  Scrambled eggs, cooked to order mixed with cheese, churizo, ham (I think) and bacon (I think) and topped off with a very runny weird tasting red sauce.  Hello, El Faro, meet potatoes.  They belong in a breakfast burrito. Enough said.  

Had I spent my Thursday night out at a bar doing car-bombs or shots of Jack Daniels I may have given the burrito an extra star as a hangover cure, greasy as it was.   Then again, the consistency of the contents may have also driven me to dash for the nearest restroom and they may still, based on the composition which for the record was about 84% grease.  

Sufficed it to say that while the people there may have been tolerant (if not nice) and the eggs were cooked on a griddle rather than microwaved, this sad excuse for a breakfast burrito comes nowhere close to the quality or the deliciousness of that served by the Foccacia cafe.  Although my search for a good breakfast burrito continues my hope wanes that anything of quality will be found before our move to 50 California, where I can be reunited with the wonder of Focaccia cafe once again.
author: Joshua F.

description:
Growing up in Southern California, I lived on good Mexican food. When I moved to the Bay Area 20 years ago, I was warned about the lack of any place that serves a good MEXICAN burrito. This place is no exception.

A completely boring, lackluster, small portioned dismal experience is what I came away with. The rice was kinda terrible. The beans were so watered down that it would be easy to drink them. The meat was so-so and the red enchilada sauce didn't do anything to it. 

All this before we even get to the decor. Eating there is like eating in a dilapidated senior care facility. Really bad wood paneling and nothing that says, "welcome to a MEXICAN Restaurant." 

The service is......adequate. No awards for warmth or even a slight smile. 

This is the sort of place that you eat at because you work in the immediate vicinity and have no other choice. But you DO have a choice! There's a Taco Truck on Tehama St. just south of Howard that's REALLY good. Just walk PAST El Faro and turn right down Tehama and go about half-way down the street. You'll be glad you did.
author: Johnny H.

description:
this place is awful and depressing. I went here just because it is close to the office. The burrito didn't taste very good and the ingredients didn't look appetizing at all. The ambiance didn't help either.

The woman who was preparing my burrito didn't know which of the beans were vegetarian.  All restaurant owners should understand that when there are vegetarians in a group they control where the group goes. So you need to please them even if you don't care about vegetarianism. 

won't go back here again.
author: saurabh S.

description:
You have to try the pork super burritos.

I don't really understand why the reviews are so low here. Before I started watching what I eat, I ate here once or twice per week. I'll still let myself splurge once every other week or so. The place is usually packed at lunch, not empty as some other reviews have said. I can't speak to the quality of their tacos or other food, but their burritos are great. The chicken can be a little greasy at times, but the beef and pork usually aren't. The pork is some of the best I've had. I will usually only drink water when I get a pork burrito because I don't want any other flavor competing for my attention. It's absolutely sublime.

The ladies that make the food can be a little brusk.  I find that to be part of the charm. They're moving quickly to keep the line moving and get the food to people. They remember regulars and what you order. The woman who usually works at the cash register is great. She's friendly, helpful, cheerful, and just provides good service.
author: Dave C.

description: I really like the nice ladies who work here but I concur with the other reviewers.  The portions are very small.  Prices are ok on average but as far as taste, that is also average.    If they really were a true mexican famiily restaurant they would add love to their food.  This place is more focused on cutting corners as if less burrito=more profit.
author: Jake S.

description: OMG!  i had the happy day burrito with carne asada.  This was so bad!!!!  first they put a guacamole that was almost turning a different color ( not he good kind).  it was lunch time and i had the bottom of the barrel meat left to go on my burrito.  i do not know if they didn't have enough or they were just skimpy, but i barely had any.  the rice was good but not enough.  A group of hot sauce that was the top layer of grease and then half a slice of tomato.   i got some lettuces. I opened up the burrito for my first bit and it was soupy.  it looked like the tortilla was holding a soup.  when i got back to work , my stomach ached and ..lets just say it went down hill from there.  never again.  oh and they only accept cash.
author: Lu R.

description:
I've only had their breakfast burrito, which I enjoy. 

The large is indeed large and contains fresh scrambled eggs, chorizo (i think), cheese, beans, some kind of sauce (mole?), and spicy salsa. There might be rice in there, too. It usually gets me through breakfast and an early lunch.

It's messy as hell but is WAAAAY better than the nasty burrito thing they serve in the 50 Fremont lobby store. 

I forget how much it is. $6 or $7? 

Cash only. 

I recommend a try if you work in the immediate vicinity.
author: Dylan ..

description:
I ordered a chile verde regular burrito. As she was making it, I was thinking it's pretty small for a almost $6 burrito. I took it back to work, it was nice and hot but after biting into it, it took several bites to get into the meat. I was quite disappointed because the meat was dry and tasted like some concoction of leftover pork and mixed in with some chile verde sauce. 

Not very good.
author: Brandon Y.

description:
I suggest not having a burrito early in the morning or you will suffer.However,being that I have eaten at the other location on the peninsula and feasted on the taco's in the past..well you would think I would have had the sense on this particular occasion to stick with that.

NOPE,so had to settle the consequences of my choices.

However,I am giving 3 stars simply for making my next visit here good because they crispy chicken tacos were good and my tummy didn't seem like it was twisting.

P.S You can have a burrito early in the morning it just depends where you get it and how it's made.
author: Dani D.

description:
Ugh.  Barely edible food and horrible service.  The spicy chicken burrito was made with meat of dubious origin and was dripping in oil.  Ordering it, I felt like I was in a prison cafeteria line.  I don't have super high standards for burritos, but I had to throw this away after a couple bites.

Serves me right for wandering into this hole without first checking Yelp.
author: B D.

description:
Good authentic taquerias are hard to come by in this part of the city partly because there are so many good ones in the Mission & because most of the other Mexican places in the area cater to the gringos. I've tried their burritos, tosadas & quesadillas & have always been more than happy w the food & the price. The service is so-so, not friendly but not rude, they are pretty much just trying to get you in & out of there which is fine by me. The burritos come topped w this delicious red sauce & a few chips. When I say a few chips I literally mean like 4-5 chips. The baby size burritos are actually a decent size & only $5. They charge for chips, don't have a salsa bar & is cash only which all take away a star but I gave the star right back because of the red sauce. 

This place should have a higher rating for sure, I think this area of the city just hates on real Mexican food!
author: Alex R.

description:
I gave this place 4 stars and it was a foolish error.  I know I have a tendency to be a pattern eater, especially at very functional lunch time (I can actually eat the same thing every day quite comfortably), but I actually haven't had lunch downtown anywhere else since writing my original review.  Might be 5 days in a row. 

And that makes El Faro as good as it gets! 

I am resolved to mix it up tomorrow, but I know that I'll be back over and over and over again.
author: Luke M.

description: My office team decided to try this place out for the first time yesterday. My co-workers got some bowl-type dish and I got a cheese & steak torta. The food was mediocre at best, and then all four of us got sick shortly thereafter; I was vomiting for about an hour. Needless to say, we will never be coming back here again.
author: Brian B.

description: I ordered the "Acapulco burrito" which was SUPPOSED to have crab, shrimp, rice and red sauce. Instead I got a smaller-than-standard burrito with IMITATION crab meat and strips of bell peppers (not mentioned in the menu), which I am allergic to. And for that I payed a couple of extra bucks more than the regular burritos. Needless to say it was a rip-off. The service wasn't exactly award-winning, either. Never again!
author: Morgan L.

description:
El Faro SF's Single Best Taco

El Faro has the taco.... The "Taco Dorado." the yummiest Mexican concoction in the bay area.  I don't know about the other two locations in SF, but the 82 1st St (between Elm St & Mission St) El Faro was known on the SF Options Exchange and as "thy taco place."  I would frequently call over orders for 30 or more Dorados from some of the pickiest people I ever had the displeasure of knowing.  The El Faro in Martinez or Pacifica doesn't serve the "Dorado," and the salsa is inferior to the SF franchise.

The Dorado is two tortilla with cheese wedged between then heated on a grill till crispy and then made into a regular taco.  The pork is delicious but the steak is an exquisite San Francisco style, party in your mouth.  

Early morning hangover suffers can benefit from El Faro's bacon egg burrito.  The hard working ladies behind the counter travel in at absurdly early hours to prepare one of the best hot salsas in the bay area.  I'd like to thank Lisa and Susan for all the years of serving this demanding customer the best Mexican Fare in town.  

The owners are true Americans Patriots and I'm proud to frequent their business.
author: jack w.

description:
La Cumbre in San Mateo is my go-to burrito house.  El Faro is a quick trip down the elevator and half a block away.  Friday I had enough time at lunch to take a quick elevator ride and walk half a block.  EL FARO IT IS!!

The food is not the greatest.  But the people working there are fabulously warm and gracious and I enjoy chatting them up.  My typical order is a Happy Burrito with Steak.  My only complaint is that the beef is in sauce rather than fresh off the grill (like La Cumbre).  Their fountain cokes are just right.  Overall, I do enjoy their food.

Some of my colleagues run over for the breakfast burrito.  I'm scared to death to start that habit as I'm a big BB fan.
author: Sparkely K.

description:
Hello little place that I pass by every day on my way outta the city.  I like that your burritos are NOT as big as my arm since I'm always driving when I'm eating them.  I also like that you have vegetarian rice and refried beans.  (I asked and no lard in the refried beans.)

I did not like that the chile relleno in today's burrito tasted a little like bacon, but I guess I didn't ask if it was fried in lard or not.  I'm not raving over your guacamole, but your hot sauce is pretty good.

My burrito today was very hot, and I was very cold until I held and consumed it.
author: Liana W.

description:
Spicy breakfast burrito, I said yeah yeah yeah!
Sooooo, lots of low ratings for this place, and maybe they're right becuase that seems to be geared toward their lunch menu which I haven't tried yet, probably never will since I'm not around there other than early morning.
My only experiences with El Faro have been with their breakfast burrito, and its simply amazing.
I always get the 'baby spicy breakfast burrito'.  I'm not sure how big the non-baby(regular) breakfast burrito is but the baby is plenty for early morning.
The spicy sauce with the eggs, cheese and CHORIZO(its so good, when it touches your lips, its so good).  I've gotten it with rice a couple of times when I wasn't in the mood for beans and it was still just as good.
So yeah, this wasn't even a debate, 5-stars for what I use this place for. It is without a doubt, the best breakfast burrito I've ever had the pleasure of devouring!
author: Ryan M.

description:
The life of a fixed income broker demands two basic things, routine--which for me means being in the office at 5 am--and food that will keep your brain pumping during that stressful multi-million dollar trade.

Now, for us unlucky souls that dare venture into this life style we must usually put up with breakfast food for lunch. Getting "lunch" at 9 am (12 pm NY time) can be somewhat challenging even in SF's FIDI. There is Birley's and Algiers which are great at making sandwiches but, what happens when you get that craving for a little latin flava early in the morning?

I trek down to El Faro and get me the greasiest carnitas burrito to curve the hunger pangs. That and this is the only place I know that is willing to sell beer to me at 9am or earlier. When I come here, I order a super burrito with guacamole and 2 beers. 15 min I'm back in the office and manning the phones.

This is not a glamor shop, its a burrito place. For me it provides beer with a side of burrito early in the morning which is just what I need for my mundane routine.
author: Carlos V.

description:
After eating here this Friday, I have now abandoned my quest for decent Mexican food in the Financial District. The place seemed pretty old school - it gave off a bit of the dingy cafeteria vibe - but for some Mexican places that's a plus, not a minus. Not so here. My chicken mole burrito was bland except for the sliced green chiles. They tossed a couple of lackluster chips on the plate and that was that.

My lunch companion speculated that people in the FiDi didn't want Mission-quality Mexican food downtown. I hope that's not true - sure, I don't want a gullet full of green chiles, but I don't want bland food either. Good food is so close, and yet, on your lunch hour it's so far away.
author: Timothy O.

description:
I actually think that the food here is quite tasty, in fact more flavorful than many other taquerias.  My biggest gripe about the place is that the burritos are so wet and soggy that sometimes it can be almost impossible to pick up and eat.  This might be why they plate them up and drench them in sauce if you eat in.  If you need to take it back to your office though good luck trying to keep it together and not have the contents running down your hands.

More often than not I stick to ordering their nachos.  They heap on the cheese which is what I like.  With the beans, salsa and sour cream they are probably the tastiest nachos you can get in the Fidi.
author: Luis M.

description:
I'm surprised by the low ratings.  I've been hitting this place up since 2000 and have never been disappointed.  This place has the best breakfast burritos I have ever had, and the best burritos that exist downtown.

If you like gringo breakfast burritos with potatoes, bell peppers, egg whites only, all wrapped up tightly (Southwestern Style), maybe this place is not for you.   If you like ham, bacon, chorizo, mixed in an egg fry, put into a steamed tortilla with re-fried beans, hot sauce, and wrapped up loosely, then this breakfast burrito is for you.

If you are feeling extra brave and hungry, hit up the bag of homemade guresos and hot salsa.  yes...the salsa is hot and hella tasty.  I have asked for the recipe multiple times, but they are not going to give it up.

The Acapulco burrito for lunch is damn good also.  I have hit the Veggie Burrito (with re-fried beans) and it was pretty good, and their Torta's are tasty, but I mostly just hit it up for breakfast.  

This place hasn't officially gotten the "Hipster Burrito Gold Star" approval rating, but give it a try, especially the breakfast burrito.  Still better and cleaner than Cancun, and tastier than other "Mission Style" hipster spots in the Mission.

Don't be fooled by the "El Faro" on Kearny.
author: Nate B.

description: Don't get me wrong their burritos are tasty. Though a bit inconsistent with the cheese and egg ratio. (You never know what you're going to get).  But the question is: Is it really worth dealing with angry latino woman with no customer service skills and who talk down to you like you're stupid? Aside from that they're also skimp on salsa; charged me 85 cents for a container's worth. Unbelievable. So let's just say that that one dwindling star I gave was for the sake of me posting this. They are not even close to entitlement of that one star.
author: Alyssa A.

description: Love this place!  I've been going here for 10 years now and I've never been disappointed, great service, great food and great location.  My fav is their cheese enchiladas plate, it's crazy good and probably the best I've had.  Please do yourself a favor and check them out, you'll be glad you did.
author: Jesse F.

description:
I thought I'd give El Faro a try, since it's near my office, and I'm always up for a taco.

I ordered two super-veggie tacos. I spent a little time explaining that, because I'm allergic to flour, they needed to cook my corn tortillas separately -- not on the grill, as they first attempted to do. So she steamed them, which is OK ... and then set them down on a stack of flour tortillas. I realize there's a language barrier there, and thankfully a fellow customer came to my rescue, but ... I doubt I will go back, for this reason alone. 

Now, on to the tacos: they were tasty, and made to order, but two cost me $7 (for vegetarian) and they included less food than I'm accustomed to getting in ONE tortilla at, say, La Corneta. 

So: not safe for my allergies, portions to small, prices too high? Nope.
author: Beth W.

description: Burritos here are not very good. Like others have said, they are pretty much just a soggy mess. The tacos here aren't bad. A better option in the general area would be Chipotle at 525 Market
author: Nick R.

description:
I can only go here when I'm 1) having a skinny day and 2) completely willing to blow that skinny day.  

I really like the burritos here.  I'm not really surprised it's rated so low - it's not the cheapest place around, the service isn't stellar, the place isn't all that nice inside, and the food isn't for everyone.  I personally like it because the flavors and ingredients remind me of my beloved tex-mex.  Refried beans, spicy runny salsa, meats stewing in their own juices, gooey cheese.  Their horchata is pretty top notch, too, when they have it.
author: K K.

description:
I only went and would continue to go because of its close proximity to my office.

Today was Day 1 of my search for a decent authentic burrito in the Financial District.  I wasn't too pleased with El Faro, so I hope Day 2 yields better results.

I ordered the Regular Burrito with carne asada and asked for additional cheese, which I didn't get.  Their burritos are pretty wet.  The sauce isn't anything special.  The steak wasn't very good, but the beans were okay.  It was mostly just loaded with rice.

The price ($5) was right, considering the location.  I'd spend an extra $2 somewhere for a higher quality burrito.
author: Travis J.

description:
I'm a bit surprised by these low ratings also, as Nate B. mentioned below.   I couldn't agree with him more that the breakfast burritos here are sooooooooooooo delicious!  It's most likely artery-clogging, but the combination of ham, bacon and chorizo, all wrapped in a warm flour tortilla with eggs, cheese and refried beans is so irresistible.  It even cured my hangover this morning!  That was the first thing I was craving when I got out of bed, and trust me, it really hits the spot.

When I'm craving a burrito for lunch, I usually come here because 1) the Mission is too far for my lunch hour, 2) it's undeniably true that there is a lack of Mexican food in the FiDi, and 3) I've tried about all the Mexican taquerias in the FiDi and have concluded that El Faro is the best out of  them all.  I usually stick to the carnitas baby burrito with spicy sauce.  It can be a little too wet and saucy sometimes, but definitely worth my $4.60.
author: Diane L.
