description: Growing up I loved El Faro in South City..... So I was excited to try El Faro SF.  OMG, they were slow as could be... Burrito was thin and soggy.  I wasn't happy with my selection.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Carne asada nachos or the chicken burrito.  These are my staples at El Faro.  It's simple food and during the busy lunch hour, you'll appreciate the speediness of the ladies behind the counter.  Not the friendliest in the world, but you get or order quick.

One word of warning - do not get a small bag of chips.  Get the big bag.  I nearly fell out of my chair when I realized that my "small" bag of chips had exactly 6 chips in it.  Counted them, six. I think those chips cost me $1.25 too.  Rip off.
author: Denise M.

description:
I used to eat here fairly regularly because it was the only Mexican place I knew of that is within my very small (re: super lazy) walking distance. 

I agree with Sparkely K. that the staff is very nice and friendly. But I also agree with Acacia T. that the food isn't great and you are nickel and dimed for every extra ingredient.
author: Dee I.

description:
BREAKFAST BURRO!

There arent even words for how much I love the breakfast burros from here. I order the baby and I am full until late afternoon. They are so yummy that I cant stop gobbling it down, but I am always sad when it is all gone.
author: Lora C.

description: This place has the mediocre food and service at best, and if that's not enough, the food poisoning will surely ruin whatever plans you have for the following several days after your visit.  The health department needs to complete a thorough  assessment as the sanitation and food preparation is likely not up to minimum standards. I would rate 0 stars if possible.
author: bill w.

description:
El Faro is Taco Hell
El Faro

82 1st St
San Francisco, CA 94105
(415) 495-4426

 

Let me start by saying this is the worse Taco experience of my life, save for Taco Bell atrocities. Taco Bell's day of reckoning in the World Court shall soon come and we shall no longer have to endure their brand of torture. Back to El Faro....What a travesty, I was starving for a quick fix of my favorite Mexican delicacy only to have my taste buds assaulted with a concoction of beef, onions and cilantro that was drowning in a salsa like substance.  I ordered it to go, by the time I got to the office (same block as El Faro) the 2 tacos were  the consistency of an enchilada drowning in sauce, I could not pick the taco up to eat because the 2 shells were collapsing from the puddle of salsa that was slathered on them. I'm also dismayed that El Faro charged me $7:16 for 2 tacos.  For that kind of money, one expects to be able to eat the product.
author: D Scott D.

description: I don't expect a Mexican place in the FiDi to be awesome but at the same time it can't be that bad either. Came here for lunch awhile back and got a burrito and wow talk about disappointed. I think one of the other reviews said it best when they described the burrito as lacking any flavor and just tasting like soppy wet re-fried beans.  I'm usually pretty forgiving but I was not happy with my food. Have not and will not go back here.
author: Hyung L.

description:
Me: Can I have one quesadilla, please?
Lady: Okay. Would you like cheese with that?
Me: Huh?!? Uh.. okay, I guess....
Lady: Oh, sorry, it's friday. I mean, do you want salsa and guacamole?

I thought the slip up was pretty funny. Anyway, on the food. I've never ordered burrito from this place, so I can't review them based on that. The quesadillas do tend to be a soggy mess. But I don't care much for presentation. I thought it was alright. And despite the bad reviews, El Faro is usually pack during lunch time, so they can't be THAT bad.
author: Ari C.

description:
It was a tasty pork burrito, it just was kinda...well...soggy.  They serve it with red sauce (think enchilada sauce) on it w/ cheese, which is fine, but the inside of the burrito should be full of fluffy rice, beans, meat, etc.  It was just...soggy, like I said.

It's not a terrible place for Mexican, food, definitely  not the best place either.  I wanted tacos but it seemed too expensive for what you get. 

I was full after lunch though, which is a good thing.  Basically, it's not that bad, but less sogginess would be much appreciated.
author: Naoko M.

description: Giving this place two stars is a gift, but at least I didn't get sick afterward, so I guess that's something. Their burritos are soupy, and by the time you're two bites into it there's water all over the plate in front of you, and the burrito's nearly fallen apart. The ingredients are nothing to write home about either. Add to that an indifferent staff and thoroughly unpleasant atmosphere and I can't think of a single reason to go back.
author: Joe F.

description:
You live, you learn.  

Not me.  I keep going back for more hurt.  This time I dined-in.  They drenched my salt-lick of a carnitas super burrito with some kind of beautiful red sauce.  It added a lot of flavor.  It was also salty enough to make me blind.  

I think there's something wrong with me lately.  Every time I eat, I feel like i just go sucker-punched in the abs.  Really hard.  And then I end up hating myself for the rest of the afternoon.
author: Christina C.

description:
I love me some Mexican food!  I'll admit, I'm not too picky with Mexican.  I'm also a fan of "hole-in-the-wall" restaurants.  One of my coworkers introduced me to El Faro.  If you want a quick burrito that's decent, then check this place out.  The service is horrible as the ladies who make the food for you remind me of the "Soup Nazi" from Seinfeld.  

I'm not sure if the horchata was bad, but there were chunks of stuff in there!  I've never had that before and I have had horchata from a many establishments.  I wasn't sure if i should  spit it out or drink it.  I drank it . . . and since I'm alive as I am typing this review, I guess I can't complain.  =)
author: Manton R.

description: Not a bad place for burritos and quesadillas.  Stay away from the togo mini nachos cuz they give you a tiny portion.  I've seen dine-in portions and those are better.  I think they got lazy about it and/or didn't want to use a larger togo container, but man I wasn't happy about that one.  Burritos are ok, not stellar, but I do enjoy their quesadillas with meat a lot and that's what I tend to get there now when I go.
author: Davey L.

description: I almost died from salt intake! The food is basically inedible.
author: Jordan F.

description: I love El Faro, but this is the best one (better than the other locations).  Their Mexican food is amazeballs, and this is THE place to go for lunch in the Financial District if you are hungry and ready for that blissful coma that only excellent Mexican food can provide.  I love this place.  No frills, just delicious food.
author: Dan R.

description:
Wow, I'm surprised by the harsh reviews here.

The breakfast burrito is very good and utterly free of vegetables.  I dig.

The regular burritos are okay or a little better, though a bit pricey for burritos.  Meat-wise, I recommend the marinated chicken (the one in the red sauce).  The pork tends to be pretty dry.

Service-wise, this place sucks.  I have language/communications problems here that are bad even by taqueria standards, probably due to the fact that the counter you order from has glass up to about 5'6", and all the employees are 5'. 

Also, beware that if you ask for jalapenos, and they forget, and you remind them as they are wrapping up your burrito, they are going to remedy the situation with a wad of peppers thrown in a clump in the middle of your burrito.  You will end up with a burrito that is mild on both ends and thermonuclear in the middle.
author: Paul B.

description: This place is quite overpriced and the food quality is middling at best. The salsa is watery and lacks flavor and the taco shells are store-bought. You pay an arm and a leg for sour cream. Go elsewhere.
author: Andrew K.

description:
El Caca is what is coming out of me after lunch today. 

My friend actually got an eye-roll when she ordered a crunchy taco *and* a soft taco. Supremely surly servitude from the burrito-makin lady, don't need it. 

Buh-bye.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
El Faro -- lousy ingredients, sloppy construction, Styrofoam plates, weak salsa, warm fountain water, dingey atmosphere. No excuse for this type of performance.

El Faro -- I quit you.
author: Eric M.

description:
El Faro...South City, CA, circa 1979.  I'm not sure but this might be the original.  Back in the day, when most of your dining choices were Fleur de Lys or Mels Drive-in, ethnic food was almost unheard of.

The burritos were HUGE with lots of stuff stuffed inside.  I just remember one burrito would last two meals.  The tacos were ok...back then, the only choice was the crispy version.  I'm not so hot on the crispy version.

Fast forward, 2007...crispy tacos here are ~$1.75 or so for one.  The soft tacos are $3.30 for one.  WTF!!!!  I'm totally not understanding why there's this huge price difference.  And when did soft tacos come with refried beans on the bottom?  I am not a fan of refried beans...

I would never try a burrito here because I've seen them assembled.  Not pretty...

There are a gazillion Mexican restaurants better than this chain.  

Co-workers with immature ethnic taste buds...very taxing.
author: Maggie K.

description:
If I could give 0 stars, I would. You could make better burritos with canned beans, pre-shredded cheese, and tortillas bought at Safeway. Inedibly bad food.

Even by the standards of other El Faro locations, this one is terrible.
author: anita c.

description:
I've always had a feeling that I did not like wet burritos...  Now it is confirmed...  I do not enjoy my burritos wet.  I wish I knew that the Happy Burrito came wet or else I would have ordered the super burrito instead.  Oh well.  Live and learn.

Oh, and at $9.01 for a Happy Burrito and horchata...  that is just too expensivo (not sure if that's a real word in Spanish, but I trust that you'll know what I mean).
author: Christine T.

description:
Okay, so the place isn't dirt cheap, and their burritos aren't monstrosities that will do battle with a leaden stomach.  On the other hand, I really don't like it when my stomach has to do battle with a burrito, expecially not if I've gotta be productive at work afterwards.  

The one redeeming quality of this place:  The "Wet" burrito is standard, none of this bullshit "Add $1.49" to make it wet.  Yes, my friends, at this location, mojado is the standard.
author: Jeffrey H.

description:
Who would go here for ambiance?  Its a hole-in-the-wall mexican joint.

The breakfast burritos are out of this world....less than $5 gets you a delish burrito with meat, spicy salsa, beans, egg and cheese - with chips.

We get breakfast burritos every friday and I look forward to them every week.
author: Fräulein J.

description:
I swing by here from time to time when I want a quick burrito because its close to my work.  Their food is so/so and there's definitely plenty of  better options for Mexican food out there.  The only thing that really stands out in my mind is their hot sauce/salsa!   I actually buy the hot sauce/salsa to go so I can bring it home with me.    As for lunch there...I just have them slap some extra hot sauce on everything and wa-la, not a bad meal at all.   

All and all I'd say that this is just a place to grab a quick lunch on the run when I don't feel like walking over to the Taco Truck on Spear St.
author: Ed B.

description: This is the WORST Mexican food I have ever eaten.  Save your money.
author: Bill G.

description:
The only thing i ever get... Carnitas Sandwich....

I'm not going to read any of the other reviews for this place only because 90% of them are probably bashing on their burritos...  i'm not going to write about their burritos.. because i've never actually had one.  I do, however, get their sandwiches.

Granted it's been a couple years since i've been back but i still crave their sandwiches from time to time..  huge roll (more like a loaf) split and toasted on the griddle..  slather on guac and fixins.  add meat cheese and peppers.  close and wrap in protective casing.  let stand for a minute as the juices get absorbed by the bread.  Peel and eat!  Mmmmmmmmm
author: Mack N.

description: El Faro was nothing special for me. It is just another little Mexican place that doesn't bring anything different to the table. Their burritos were good but a bit small and I thought it lacked the quality of taste that even the chains in the area can provide.
author: Andrew M.

description: I got a stomach from eating the Acapulco burrito.  It had to be the crab sauce--I can taste it.  The staff was friendly.
author: Clear P.

description:
cheap dirty yet delish burrito in financial/soma? this is the place!

found this little delight yesterday craving some mexican for lunch. co-worker bought me here; i ordered a regular burrito with pork, spicy. 

it is AMAZING. so simple, just meat, rice and beans. but the hot sauce is fantastic, and the entire burrito-eating experience just made me want to cry a little from its finger-licking pleasure. no other distracting components, the hot warm combination was so good i wished the eating process could last forever. 

will definitely go back when i want something cheap, warm and just the right amount of 'authentic dirtiness'. 

don't order the 'mini' burrito like my coworker did. it is not enough. it never is.


ps: don't come here for service/ambiance- rookie mistake.
author: Fiona S.

description:
i am always in favor of a restaurant that serves the little people who need little portions. they're baby burrito is the best size for me. i can't say much for their standard chips & salsa, but they make a great burrito in petite size.

always helpful...bring cash! they don't accept cards whatsoever.
author: Marjie T.

description: Go a block down on 2nd street if you want better food. This place sucks for so many reasons: no salsa bar / no chips / small loosely wrapped burritos (I ordered a Super)  / no grilled chicken (only marinated - and it was in cubes) / no pico de gallo unless you ask / bland
author: Pete v.

description: Okay - I have 3 people RAVING about their nachos.  I have come in just to watch them make it, and such love and care is taken!  They spreak out the chips evenly, with care sprinkles the beans, and then the cheeese... then warms up the cheese for a couple of minutes.  The they will lovingly spread the (yucky, limey, not fresh) guacamole, sour cream, then any (if any) meat right on top.  Definitely made with love!  Unfortunately - if you loving spread poo... make it all pretty... it's still poo :(  I didn't like it - the chips were a bit oily, and the quacamole was runny and bitter.  Ick :(
author: Lea R.

description: Wow, you can trust all the bad reviews of this place. No chips, only one choice of beans (refried) and something tasted seriously off with the guacamole. When trying to figure out what kind of meat to choose for my burrito, taking a glance at the food bins didn't inspire confidence. I mean, usually you can tell which is the carnitas and which is the chicken, but I couldn't tell for sure. It was all the same color and consistency. I settled for the pollo asado, but I have to say that it didn't taste great. I should have walked the extra blocks to Maya.
author: Tom H.

description:
The breakfast burrito, complete with egg that features fried-in chorizo, cheese, beans, the special sauce, and a full smattering of sour cream - is perhaps the greatest thing I've ever experienced in my life.

I have not tried the different menu items.

I have not eaten here at any time but breakfast.

BUT - I have tried many a breakfast burrito, including every restaurant anywhere near close to my office - I have yet to experience another burrito even remotely close to this. So full and juicy, bursting at the seams with the psuedo-Mexican flavors that you can only get from the greatest of bastardized Northern Californian burritos. This is the pinnacle of greatness, friends.
author: Jared S.

description: Gross burritos and WAY overpriced.  It looks like it used to be a deli, they even left a sign up for ordering sandwiches.  The beans are pure brown liquid.  The guacamole is green liquid.  The seafood burrito is horrendous.  I like the lady at the register though, she's nice.  But the lady who takes your order is kinda mean.
author: Skeptical Spee ..

description: Blame it on the rain...  So I walk out of my building and see big fat rain drops but I want a good burrito not a lame one from Baja Fresh, so I say what the heck let's give El Faro another chance.  I had been here years ago, pre-Yelping days and thought it was just ok.  I went for the Super chile verde and got a tiny burrito.  For being Super they sure are skimpy here.  The meat choices don't look that great, why is the carne asada in red sauce?  Carne Asada means grilled meat right?  Anyways taste wise it worked somewhat, a little on the salty side.  They also charge extra for chips, which I have come to expect in downtown SF.  They were ok, at least they weren't tostitos I suppose.  I guess next time even in the rain I need to go up a few blocks and stick with Rico Mex which makes a much better burrito.
author: La C.

description: This place is terrible.  They charge far too much for lackluster, bland, runny excuses for a burrito.  An ugly cafeteria-like setting helps seal the deal... this place will definitely not be remembered in the Scrolls of Legend.
author: critical Francis ..

description:
I ordered a veggie burrito with black beans only to see the lady making it slather a gulping layer of refried beans (not a big fan of the refried) I told her politely that I asked for black beans, she gave me a look as if I was a big inconvenience to her and then splattered a layer of black beans on top of the refried... huh, who would want that,disgusting???!!!!   I said something to the effect (politely again) "I'm sorry but I only want black beans, no refried please"  She continued with making this glob like mass obviously ignoring me,  with that I said bluntly "I'm sorry but I'm not going to eat that".  She gave me a darting glare as if I had just told her her baby was ugly, picked up the mess she created and flumped it as loudly as possible into the garbage can.  She then proceeded to make a new , for lack of a better word, "burrito" that I will have to say was the nastiest supposed burrito I have ever had, served up with an extra serving of bad attitude.  This thing was pretty much unedible so it too went loudly into the garbage can, only it was my garbage can this time..

Congrats El Farto you get the prize....
NASTIEST BURRITO ....EVER!!!

have a nice day (unless you work at El Farto)
author: G L.

description: Their chile verde burrito is pretty damn good.  But the chips are some of the worst I've ever tasted, and they don't even give you any salsa to dip them in.  I still go here for lunch, but that's just because they're close.
author: Rusty S.

description: Ugh another low-quality burrito shop in downtown.  This place is the usual burrito shop.  I ordered a burrito and it came out drenched wet.  I guess this is a wet burrito now?  The sauce was bland and the burrito was small.
author: Elliot Y.

description: This place is the shiznet!!! When I get the burrito craving during lunch, This is where I will be. Nothing less than the burrito supreme, carne asada with everything and extra sour cream yummmmm. This is what I consider authentic mexican food not that baja fresh crap.
author: Mark J.

description: Mediocre, runny burritos that really aren't as cheap as they should be. Avoid, given the other great options in the area.
author: Rohan N.

description: I can always count on coming here during lunch hour and find a seat for me and all my coworkers brave enough to have Mexican food for lunch.  Their service isn't great, and it's a little pricey, but the food is pretty good and the place is relatively clean.  Maybe I just have very low expectations when it comes to lunch?
author: Jenny L.

description: My co-worker and  I came in and order our food a  fat lady who takes the order and prepares it didn't seem to be happy with us and stuck a chip into our burritos. We did'nt like that cus it seem that she was pissed off we spoke tp the manager and they just told us she's been having marriage problems my coworker stated we dont care what her problems are the service is bad and they have had alot of complaints and this is the manager telling us. We decided not come back cause you never know if the fat lady will spit on our food. Unbelivable.
author: jerry p.

description: I would never go there again, I ordered a grilled chicken burrito at lunch today, but the meat was not fully cooked.  The guacomole is the worse, not worth ordering on your meal, it looks like runny green water, no guacomole consistency :-(  Unfortunately, I took my burrito to go and did not have time to return it to get a refund; definitely will NEVER purchase food there again.
author: D C.

description: Yawn, yawn, yawn.  The veggie burrito was so BORING.  I also was very peeved that they gave me no salsa.  Hey cheapskates, try increasing your profit margin by serving good food to get repeat customers!
author: CAKE E.

description: This is the only El Faro or even the only Mexican restaurant that doesn't look at me weird when I ask for mayo instead of sour cream in my burrito (you got to at least try it once if you never have).  The service is nice, and they have a wide variety on their menu, but I probably would've given it three stars if they didn't charge for tortilla chips.
author: Rommel N.

description: El Faro has some good food and a few locations downtown which make it very convenient.  I am a fiend for the breakfast burritos they have and would recommend them for anybody looking for a quick and filling meal.
author: David H.

description: Burritos are good. Hot and made to order. Kind of small in my opinion and pricey. It's 6 bucks for a breakfast burrito, but it does taste decent. Not the best deal in town. No chips to go with it either. If you want chips it's another 1.50 or salsa is another 1 something. Nickel and dime everything which makes people consider other places for lunch.
author: Allan T.

description: For an El Faro, this one is so-so. The burritos are fine/ok/average, but when you walk out with a burrito and a can of coke, you flip out even more when the staff... fills a salad spoon's worth of meat, yet seems to generously fill their mitts with lettuce. Yeah, it's downtown, but even if this place was on the corner of Montgomery and California it'd still be the biggest Mexican rip-off in SF.
author: K B.

description:
I was torn over whether to give El Faro two stars or three.  I ended up giving three because although El Faro sucks slightly, I keep coming back.  That's gotta mean something.

I have read others' reviews saying that they do not like the red sauce on top of their burritos.  I however love it.  I find their food to be inconsistent.  Sometimes the rice is undercooked, sometimes it's overcooked.  Sometimes the carnitas is tender and other times it seems dry.  They always put guacamole in my burritos (I have witnessed it each and every time), and somehow when I cut into my lunch I never see or taste the guac.  I hate their chips.  I am shocked to read that anyone would pay for them.  I also feel like the burritos are expensive and I don't think they're very big at all.  I am a slender girl with a very normal appetite.  I can finish a burrito from El Faro easily when I can not finish one at most other places.  I ordered a baby burrito once ($5) since I wasn't that hungry, but I regretted it.  It was truly a baby burrito.  I ordered a super burrito today ($6.35) and did not think it was much bigger.

Some days my food is inexplainably good.  Other days it is inexplainably bad.  I can never figure out what makes their burritos good one day and bad the next.  It's weird.
author: Kandi K.

description:
I passed by this place a multitude of times, wondering what lurked within.  When a friend recommended this place, I decided to venture in and try it out.  

I had a tamale and two crispy tacos.  The tacos were horrible, greasy, full of weird chewy bits, and had a very peculiar tasting hot sauce.  The tamale was microwaved with a styrofoam container (is that safe?).  mMMMmm, no.  Actually, it tasted alright though, but definitely isn't a way to win a regular customer.  And I was quite surprised to find that there wasn't any hot sauce on the tables to use (but there was salt and pepper).  Who puts salt and pepper on their mexi-food?  

Not horrendous, but definitely not good.
author: Eric T.

description: I used to drop by here at least once a week before going to work for the breakfast burrito.  It's huge, so I ate half for breakfast, and the other half at lunch.  I believe my stomach must have xpanded as I exercised it to chow down all that good, fattening carbo---yet, it was soooo tasty.
author: Kui T.

description: This place was last inspected on 2/20/08. It should be rated immediately before the next year is up!  A friend of mine were looking for a place to eat lunch and popped into this place. I haven't been in here awhile. It's nice to know that 1) the place and decor have NOT changed, 2) the service from the entire staff is a dismal to the say the least if not terrible! and 3) the food may be cheap, but you get what you pay for. I ordered a simple Super Burrito with no beans.  As I paid for both my meal and my friends, we sat down and were ready to chow down.  Halfway towards the end of my burrito I noticed something. I looked at my food and noticed a long dark hair .  At first I thought it may be mine until I realized it was all the way inside of my food.  I immediately was turned off.  Picked up my plate and set it in the bucket for removal.  Why didn't I tell the staff?  With a wonderful personality that they all had, do you think I would even attempt it???
author: O ..

description:
Today a colleague recommended El Faro on 1st as "the best burrito within walking distance" of our Cali/Front St. location.  He needs to dramatically expand his walkable range if this indeed is the case.

Ultimately, the burrito itself surprised on the upside after the grim experience of viewing its assembly:  soupy beans, a teaspoon of crusty carnitas scraped from the dregs of a dodgy chafing dish, "spicy sauce" languishing in the tepid range clearly proscribed by public health code.

Walking back with bag in hand, I chastised myself for ignoring the mass of yelpers and following the lead of a single coworker.  Yet once unwrapped and in my mouth, the salty, slightly spicy goodness that is a carnitas burrito tamed my ire.  

This was an OK burrito - no more or less.  I'll keep looking.
author: KJ B.

description:
I have to agree, NASTY, and OVERPRICED

Where is the good Mexican Food in this area? BAJA fresh is better than this place, but even it does not compare to the rest of the city.

I went here once for breakfast because I was desperate for a good breakfast burrito. By the time I peeled off the foil the tortilla just ripped apart all over the place because the refried beans were so runny.

I thought I would go another time to try the enchiladas, what a joke. You call that enchiladas? In a town full of great Taquerias, how does this one keep making money?
author: John M.

description: a little pricey for what it is, but their baby breakfast burritos are really delicious. what makes it special is the hot sauce they use - it's got a sweet/smoky flavor to it that rounds out the chorizo+egg+warm tortilla combo really well. definitely hits the spot if you're looking for something to hold you through 'til lunch - and something to warm your bones (and tummy) on a cold sf-fidi morning.
author: Brian L.

description: I always forget about this place when I'm trying to decide where to eat lunch, which is probably best considering how bad for the waistline it is. But when I'm ready for some Mexican cuisine indulgence, this is a great place. You can't beat the value, especially in downtown SF. I gave it four stars because the food is good (from my experience), but the service isn't always the best. One time I stood in line for a million years and waited to order from the person my friend ordered from, which turned out to be a huge mistake because I somehow kept getting passed over to order. The other times I've been it's been fine though. I'm kind of scared reading these other reviews; but I feel like, hey, if you're paying $5 for a burrito, get over the fact that the establishment is not high class. Last time I was there I ate the Acapulco burrito, which is loaded with shrimp and which I highly recommend.
author: Lisa F.

description: My favorite downtown taqueria.  Good mexican food, good prices.
author: Heather E.

description: blechh... a salty gut bomb that doesn't hold up to other mexican offerings in the FiDi!  let's see what's wrong here....  the refried beans were salty, the pollo asado was substandard tasting, not enough guac, the salsa was bland and to top it off the tortilla was not even steamed correctly!  the edges were hard!  whatever... NAAAAHSTEEEEE!
author: Swarup B.

description: Straight up this place is a piece of shit but I love the cheese enchiladas.  I don't expect anyone to actually enjoy it, but I love it.
author: Jerry T.

description: Super Breakfast Burrito.  My rating is based solely upon the fact that they can make a breakfast burrito the right way, the sloppy way...but in the Financial District!  Opens early for those of us who have to wake up when it's dark outside.
author: Benson J.

description: I've been here a couple of times. What makes this place different is that they pour sauce over your burrito making it a "wet burrito". They're HUGE and you have to eat it with a knife and fork. I usually get the regular burrito (decent) but today I decided to go for the Chicken Mole burrito after a co-worker told me its supposed to be like chocolate flavored chicken! chocolate chicken? whaat?! Well I didn't taste the chocolate at all but it had a very nice smokey flavor to it. I loved it! Should definitely give it a try!
author: Albert C.
